instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power button.
threads.message:
Hello, i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wich doesnt turn on with the power button (you need to unplug the battery and connect the charger for it to turn on, or short the 2 turn on pads).

I dont see corrosion anywhere on the board, but there is no continuity from Pin 20 of J4800 to <RESISTOR>R5116</RESISTOR>. There is continuity on the rest of the rail up to the SMC. 

Should  i solder a wire from pin 20 to <RESISTOR>R5116</RESISTOR>? Thank you.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power button.
threads.message: Oh, i forgot, already tried different keyboard, different trackpad cable, and different trackpad.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power button.
threads.message:
If <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads work, then run the wire to pin 20 of J4800.
Be sure is no short there.

threads.title: MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power button.
threads.message: Yes, i ran the wire and now the button works perfectly. Thank you.
